docs.lead_paragraph: California in November will vote on whether to raise a four-decade-old cap on medical malpractice awards to $1.1 million, from $250,000, officials said on Thursday, likely ensuring a bitter and costly fight between lawyers backing the measure and doctors who oppose it.

headline.main: California Voters to Consider Raising Four-Decade-Old Cap on Medical Malpractice Awards
headline.print_headline: California Voters to Consider Raising Four-Decade-Old Cap on Medical Malpractice Awards

docs.snippet: California in November will vote on whether to raise a four-decade-old cap on medical malpractice awards to $1.1 million, from $250,000, officials said on Thursday, likely ensuring a bitter and costly fight between lawyers backing the measure and...

docs.lead_paragraph: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana is seeking federal Medicaid funds to expand state health coverage of the poor; many recipients would pay $3 to $25 a month.

headline.main: Indiana Seeks More Coverage for Poor, but Many Would Pay
headline.print_headline: Indiana Seeks More Coverage for Poor, but Many Would Pay

docs.abstract: Indiana Gov Mike Pence proposes using federal Medicaid funds available under Affordable Care Act to expand state health insurance program to cover additional 350,000 low-income adults; many participants would pay $3 to $25 a month; Pence is among several Republican governors who have opposed expanding traditional Medicaid, calling it a failure, yet have pursued federal money for alternative models.
docs.snippet: Gov. Mike Pence of Indiana is seeking federal Medicaid funds to expand state health coverage of the poor; many recipients would pay $3 to $25 a month.

keywords.value: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: A Medicare pilot program aims to use vast volumes of government data to direct assistance to potentially vulnerable people, but it has raised privacy concerns.

headline.main: U.S. Mines Personal Health Data to Find the Vulnerable in Emergencies
headline.print_headline: U.S. Mines Personal Health Data to Find the Vulnerable in Emergencies

docs.abstract: Medicare pilot program aims to use vast volumes of government data mined from personal health records to direct assistance to potentially vulnerable people in emergencies and disasters; effort, however well-intentioned, raises privacy concerns.
docs.snippet: A Medicare pilot program aims to use vast volumes of government data to direct assistance to potentially vulnerable people, but it has raised privacy concerns.

docs.lead_paragraph: Ms. Walters has been the queen of the TV celebrity “get.” But stars and politicians no longer need the networks to reach their public.

headline.main: As Barbara Walters Retires, the Big TV Interview Signs Off, Too
headline.print_headline: As Barbara Walters Retires, the Big TV Interview Signs Off, Too

docs.abstract: Barbara Walters, 84-year-old queen of the television celebrity 'big get,' is retiring after five decades in television; she turned the celebrity interview into a kind of art form, but ratings have plunged in crowded environment with stars and politicians turning to social media, and no longer needing networks, to reach their public.
docs.snippet: Ms. Walters has been the queen of the TV celebrity “get.” But stars and politicians no longer need the networks to reach their public.

docs.lead_paragraph: Several notable indicators of economic health, including the Consumer Price Index, finally seem to be moving in the direction the Federal Reserve says is needed for a strong recovery.

headline.main: At Last, Recovery Heads Where the Fed Wants It
headline.print_headline: At Last, Recovery Heads Where the Fed Wants It

docs.abstract: Government data shows modestly higher inflation and more robust job market, two indicators of economic health that Federal Reserve and its chairwoman Janet L Yellen have identified as keys to stronger recovery; rise in Consumer Price Index in April suggests broader economic firming is underway; nascent signs of rebound stand in stark contrast to economic landscape in Europe.
docs.snippet: Several notable indicators of economic health, including the Consumer Price Index, finally seem to be moving in the direction the Federal Reserve says is needed for a strong recovery.

docs.lead_paragraph: Paltry competition in some markets results in some areas charging much more for the same level of health insurance.

headline.main: One Reason Health Insurance Premiums Vary So Much

docs.snippet: Paltry competition in some markets results in some areas charging much more for the same level of health insurance.

keywords.name: subject

docs.lead_paragraph: The V.A.’s acting inspector general told a Senate committee that federal prosecutors are looking to determine whether criminal violations occurred at a medical center in Phoenix accused of falsifying data or creating secret waiting lists.

headline.main: Official Says Prosecutors Are Looking at V.A. Lists
headline.print_headline: Official Says Prosecutors Are Looking at V.A. Lists

docs.abstract: Richard J Griffin, acting inspector general of Veterans Affairs Dept, tells Senate committee that federal prosecutors are looking to determine whether criminal violations occurred at a medical center in Phoenix accused of falsifying data or creating secret waiting lists; scrutiny is growing over medical treatment received by veterans, and some Republican senators are calling for resignation of Secretary of Veterans Affairs Eric Shinseki.
docs.snippet: The V.A.’s acting inspector general told a Senate committee that federal prosecutors are looking to determine whether criminal violations occurred at a medical center in Phoenix accused of falsifying data or creating secret waiting lists.

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite a federal court order against their current law, Missouri legislators voted Thursday to toughen requirements even further for people seeking to work as insurance guides under President Barack Obama's health care law.

headline.main: Missouri Backs Criminal Checks for Health Advisers
headline.print_headline: Missouri Backs Criminal Checks for Health Advisers

docs.snippet: Despite a federal court order against their current law, Missouri legislators voted Thursday to toughen requirements even further for people seeking to work as insurance guides under President Barack Obama's health care law.

docs.lead_paragraph: Consumers who purchased new health plans from Blue Shield of California have sued the insurer, claiming they were misled into thinking the insurance would cover their desired doctors and hospitals.

headline.main: California Consumers Say Duped by Blue Shield's Limited Obamacare Plans
headline.print_headline: California Consumers Say Duped by Blue Shield's Limited Obamacare Plans

docs.snippet: Consumers who purchased new health plans from Blue Shield of California have sued the insurer, claiming they were misled into thinking the insurance would cover their desired doctors and hospitals.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration has given the go-ahead for insurers and employers to use a new cost-control strategy that puts a hard dollar limit on what health plans pay for some expensive procedures, such as knee and hip replacements.

headline.main: New Health Cost Controls Get Go-Ahead From Feds
headline.print_headline: New Health Cost Controls Get Go-Ahead From Feds

docs.snippet: The Obama administration has given the go-ahead for insurers and employers to use a new cost-control strategy that puts a hard dollar limit on what health plans pay for some expensive procedures, such as knee and hip replacements.
